message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination point towards Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by frameshift mutations in the DMD gene. Same sense or missense mutations can cause less severe forms of muscular dystrophy, while splice site mutations can cause either mild or severe forms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest muscular dystrophy, a genetic disorder that causes progressive weakness and loss of muscle mass. Frameshift mutations are the most severe type of mutation, as they result in a shift in the reading frame of the genetic code, leading to a shortened or altered protein. Frameshift mutations are likely responsible for the most severe clinical presentation of muscular dystrophy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation of the patient suggests Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a frameshift mutation. This type of mutation disrupts the reading frame of the genetic code, resulting in a truncated or abnormal protein which affects muscle function. Same sense and missense mutations affect the protein structure but may not result in a severe presentation. Splice site mutations affect the mRNA processing and may result in different types of mutations, but do not necessarily lead to a severe presentation like frameshift mutations.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described suggest a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a frameshift mutation in the dystrophin gene. This mutation results in the absence of functional dystrophin protein, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy. Same sense, missense, and splice site mutations can also affect the dystrophin gene but are less severe in their clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Frameshift mutations, such as the deletion or insertion of nucleotides, will lead to a nonfunctional or truncated protein, resulting in the most severe clinical presentation. Same sense, missense, and splice site mutations can also cause Duchenne muscular dystrophy, but they generally result in less severe symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by mutations in the DMD gene. Frameshift mutations, which involve the deletion or insertion of nucleotides, are the most severe types of mutations and are commonly associated with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Missense mutations only change one amino acid and are less severe, while splice site mutations affect the splicing of mRNA and can have varying degrees of severity. Same sense mutations involve the same amino acid and are typically silent or have a mild effect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation suggest Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a frameshift mutation in the DMD gene on the X chromosome. This mutation disrupts the production of functional dystrophin, leading to progressive weakness and eventual loss of muscle function. Same sense mutation, missense mutation, and splice site mutation can also cause muscular dystrophy, but Duchenne muscular dystrophy is specifically caused by a frameshift mutation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the waddling gait and muscle weakness, suggest a muscle disease called Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Frameshift mutations are the most severe type of mutations and can cause a truncated protein, which is the case in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Same sense mutations, missense mutations, and splice site mutations are less severe and may lead to milder forms of the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest a diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is caused by a frameshift mutation in the dystrophin gene. This results in the complete absence of dystrophin, a protein essential for the normal structure of muscle fibers. The other mutations listed are also seen in muscular dystrophies, but frameshift mutations in the dystrophin gene are specific to Duchenne muscular dystrophy and associated with its severe clinical presentation.

We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation mentioned in the question are suggestive of Duchenne muscular dystrophy. A frameshift mutation, which causes a deletion or insertion of nucleotides, is most likely to cause a frameshift in the reading frame of the gene, leading to a truncated or non-functional protein, which can lead to severe cases of the disease. Same sense, missense, and splice site mutations may also cause the disease but may not result in such severe clinical presentation.
